messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: my photo album, pictures 19 and 20
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Elliott and Curran; Elliott, I know how you feel and can sympathize with your frustration.  Unfortunately it is a part of the learning curve associated with
messages.messageBody:
Hi Elliott and Curran;

Elliott, I know how you feel and can sympathize with your frustration. Unfortunately it is a part of the learning curve associated with this hobby.

As far as the dealers go, many of the people who have tables at shows are not dealers. They are collectors who are upgrading their collections, just like you, in San Fran by selling pieces that have nothing left to teach them and buying new ones that they hope to learn from. The majority of these people have the same limited knowledge selling their items as you did buying it.

I doubt if they had any intent to mislead you, they just did not know any better. Unfortunately this is true in most instances. The seller has very little idea as to what he or she is selling. This in my experience this applies equally to blades that are gime, and fittings that are less than what they may be demonstrated as.

The dealers who make their living buying and selling swords and fittings know exactly what they are selling, and if they should make a mistake, they will look after you.

Its all part of the learning curve.

John




----- Original Message -----
From: Elliott
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Monday, November 06, 2006 8:44 AM
Subject: [nihontostudy] Re: my photo album, pictures 19 and 20


Curran,

I apologize, I sometimes 'leap before looking'! There are very few
dealers that one must be careful of. Asking a lot of questions,
getting a lot of opinions is critical for my survival along with the
other 'newbees'. But, the dealer that sold me this piece (19 & 20
photos)was not honest with me. I ask the right questions and got
incorrect answers. As I said, "I have learned from this experiance."

The Saotome has a Shakudo rim.

Thank you very much,

Elliott

PS; I admit making an ass out of myself sometimes.....I hate when
that happens.

--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, Curran Campbell
<neobliviscar@...> wrote:
>
> Elliott,
>
> No matter how hard we may try, I think all of us make
> an ass of ourselves at one time or another. I
> certainly have. By sticking my neck out and giving an
> opinion here, I've probably just ticked off a dealer
> who now is going to send evil thoughts my way.
>
> There are a lot of dealers out there who are very
> honest and take small profit for their pains. Do them
> credit.
> Lordy knows it pains me to go through the process
> of selling anything. Absolutely hate to even try! This
> past year I picked up 2 lots of exceptionally good
> tsuba and am only going to keep about 40% of them. I'm
> in the process of papering them (slow process)and
> deciding which to keep. I planned to let an auction
> house sell them, but learned the auction houses get
> their pound of flesh! Unless I give them over $100,000
> of items... they take a greater % than any dealer I
> know.
> As the tsuba come back from Japan, I'll just put
> them out at Tampa sword show and possibly Chicago--
> but ultimately a few of them will probably end up with
> a dealer.
>
> So go easy on the dealers. Many are good people who
> provide a service to buyers and sellers. There are 2
> or 3 I call friend.
>
> Curran
>
> Ps. The 'Saotome' have a shakudo edge?
>
>
>
>

> >

> >
> > The Saotome piece I have in my album is fabulous. I
> > should hope to
> > never sell it.
> >
> > Thanks,
> >
> > Elliott
> >
> >
> > --- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, Curran Campbell
> >

> > > Elliott,

> > > The good:

> > I
> > > like the Sukeyoshi and the one labeled Saotome.
> > >
> > > The bad:
> > > Photos #19 & #20 are of a shiiremono (mass

> > > tsuba. It might even be one of the better modern

> > > > Tsuba. I have taken
> > > > a shot at the characteristics of this piece.
> > Just
> > > > point me in a

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: my photo album, pictures 19 and 20
messages.msgSnippet: Milt, Quote: Mito Shiiremono was just for *study s sake*. I didn t know if Torigoye had much on the Nagoya/Yokohama shiiremono, so I just mentioned the Mito
messages.messageBody:
Milt,

Quote: Mito Shiiremono was just for *study's sake*.

I didn't know if Torigoye had much on the
Nagoya/Yokohama shiiremono, so I just mentioned the
Mito shiiremono. Does the Nihonto Koza Kodogu volume
have much on the Nagoya shiiremono.
As far as I'm concerned, same difference. But
concerning Elliott's tsuba- Nagoya/Yokohama is
probably more correct.

Mass produced is mass produced.

Curran

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: my photo album, pictures 19 and 20
messages.msgSnippet: Elliott, No matter how hard we may try, I think all of us make an ass of ourselves at one time or another. I certainly have. By sticking my neck out and giving
messages.messageBody:
Elliott,

No matter how hard we may try, I think all of us make
an ass of ourselves at one time or another. I
certainly have. By sticking my neck out and giving an
opinion here, I've probably just ticked off a dealer
who now is going to send evil thoughts my way.

There are a lot of dealers out there who are very
honest and take small profit for their pains. Do them
credit.
Lordy knows it pains me to go through the process
of selling anything. Absolutely hate to even try! This
past year I picked up 2 lots of exceptionally good
tsuba and am only going to keep about 40% of them. I'm
in the process of papering them (slow process)and
deciding which to keep. I planned to let an auction
house sell them, but learned the auction houses get
their pound of flesh! Unless I give them over $100,000
of items... they take a greater % than any dealer I
know.
As the tsuba come back from Japan, I'll just put
them out at Tampa sword show and possibly Chicago--
but ultimately a few of them will probably end up with
a dealer.

So go easy on the dealers. Many are good people who
provide a service to buyers and sellers. There are 2
or 3 I call friend.

Curran

Ps. The 'Saotome' have a shakudo edge?

messages.subject: Re: my photo album, pictures 19 and 20
messages.msgSnippet: ... Looks more like Nagoya/Yokohama dock side specials. Does not look like Mito school to me. Since no  big money  changed hands.......... it s one of those
messages.messageBody:
--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, Curran Campbell
<neobliviscar@...> wrote:
>
> Elliott,
>
> >
> The bad:
> Photos #19 & #20 are of a shiiremono (mass produced)
> tsuba. It might even be one of the better modern
> chinese repros. For study's sake, look up Mito
> Shiiremono.
>

Looks more like Nagoya/Yokohama dock side specials.
Does not look like Mito school to me.

Since no " big money " changed hands.......... it's one of those "
what not to wear " kind of thingie, good as a reminder when
imagination runs wild.


I have one " soft metal " dragon in the cloud tsuba with fine nanako,
very high relief carving of the dragon . From the pics it looks good
( after two glasses of Yellow Tail ) but in hand it just gives out "
bad vibs " like Three Miles Island.

Milt

messages.subject: Re: my photo album, pictures 19 and 20
messages.msgSnippet: Curran, Thank you! And it only hurts a little. I bought this tsuba and another from one of the many dealers who spout their so-called knowledge of Nihonto
messages.messageBody:
Curran,

Thank you! And it only hurts a little.

I bought this tsuba and another from one of the many 'dealers' who
spout their so-called knowledge of Nihonto but don't know their ass
from a hole-in-the-ground (and who will remain nameless). I learned
a very good lesson..........Be very careful about what you are being
sold and how much money your spending. Since they didn't cost me
alot, this lesson was worth the money.

As soon as I take some pictures of the other, I will submit them for
a consult.

The Saotome piece I have in my album is fabulous. I should hope to
never sell it.

Thanks,

Elliott

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] my photo album, pictures 19 and 20
messages.msgSnippet: Elliott, The good: There are some nice tsuba in your in your folder. I like the Sukeyoshi and the one labeled Saotome. The bad: Photos #19 & #20 are of a
messages.messageBody:
Elliott,

The good:
There are some nice tsuba in your in your folder. I
like the Sukeyoshi and the one labeled Saotome.

The bad:
Photos #19 & #20 are of a shiiremono (mass produced)
tsuba. It might even be one of the better modern
chinese repros. For study's sake, look up Mito
Shiiremono.

The ugly:
There is no sharpness or crispness to the design. The
nanako (little beads) are crudely spaced. The figures
are poorly cut, and gold washed.


Curran



--- Elliott <elliott@...> wrote:

> Dear group,
>
> First let me say it is a priviledge to have access
> to all of your
> opinions. I can only hope that thru years of study
> that I may obtain
> some of the knowledge this group possesses.

> Now my question..........If you would go to
> 'elliotts photos' and look
> at numbers 19 and 20 (click on them), I am trying to
> determine the
> school and time (early, middle, late Edo) of this
> Tsuba. I have taken
> a shot at the characteristics of this piece. Just
> point me in a
> direction to study.
>
> Thank you all,
>
> Elliott
>
>
>

messages.subject: my photo album, pictures 19 and 20
messages.msgSnippet: Dear group, First let me say it is a priviledge to have access to all of your opinions. I can only hope that thru years of study that I may obtain some of the
messages.messageBody:
Dear group,

First let me say it is a priviledge to have access to all of your
opinions. I can only hope that thru years of study that I may obtain
some of the knowledge this group possesses.

Now my question..........If you would go to 'elliotts photos' and look
at numbers 19 and 20 (click on them), I am trying to determine the
school and time (early, middle, late Edo) of this Tsuba. I have taken
a shot at the characteristics of this piece. Just point me in a
direction to study.

Thank you all,

Elliott
